snippet: As the hunt for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet pushed into the Indian Ocean, a satellite company, Inmarsat, said it had recorded electronic signals that could prove to be the first big break in helping narrow the search.
abstract: Satellite company Inmarsat says it has recorded electronic signals that could prove to be the first big break in helping narrow the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, as hunt for missing jet pushes into Indian Ocean.

byline.original: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and NICOLA CLARK
byline.contributor: Chris Buckley reported from Sepang, Malaysia, and Nicola Clark from Paris. Reporting was contributed by Michael Forsythe from Penang, Malaysia; Keith Bradsher from Sepang; Gardiner Harris from New Delhi; and Eric Schmitt, Michael S. Schmidt and Matthew L. Wald from Washington.

lead_paragraph: As the hunt for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet pushed into the Indian Ocean, a satellite company, Inmarsat, said it had recorded electronic signals that could prove to be the first big break in helping narrow the search.

headline.main: Satellite Firm Says Its Data Could Offer Location of Missing Flight
headline.print_headline: Satellite Firm Says Its Data Could Offer Location of Missing Flight
